characters: INT. FRANCES AND SOPHIE'S APARTMENT. DAYS LATER. MORNING
INT. CAB FROM JFK. LATE DAY
NOT THE ONE IN THE LIVING ROOM THE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find Frances and Sophie, both 27, setting up a little performance space in front of a statue.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Okay, ready?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yep. Sophie sings and plays a shitty guitar badly. Frances dances. When people walk by, they both stop and yell:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES AND SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Give us your MONEY!!! They laugh. Sometimes someone will give them change. Usually a creepy guy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (alone now) Give us-- (laughs) Come on!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES AND SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Give us your money!!! CUT TO: Music swells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances and Sophie run through the park together. They 3 dump what little money they earned into another musician's guitar case. Frances makes sure to keep a dollar bill. They run into the subway. 4 Subway. Sophie sits. Frances stands above her. She 5 leans down to say something. Frances cooks. Scrambled eggs and stir fry. Sophie 6 enters frame and gets plates out of the cupboard.  10

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I tried a frittata but it’s more of a scramble. Frances is reading and Sophie is knitting. 7

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, this is interesting. She reads a sentence out loud from “Sincerity and Authenticity” by Lionel Trilling. Sophie nods. Sophie works out to a video in the tiny living room. 8 Frances half watches. Frances and Sophie smoke in two separate adjacent 9 windows. They both lean outside. We see them talking outside the windows. They sit across from each other in their living room. 10

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (doing a Jamaican accent) Okay, my father is from Jamaica, mon, and-- (doing an Irish accent) --my mother is from Ireland. (trying to combine the accents) So I talk like this... They both crack up.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (doing a Russian accent) My mother is from Russia and-- (doing a Southern accent) --and my father is from Alabama. (trying to combine) So I talk like this. They play a game together. 10A They do their laundry at the laundromat across the 11 street. They both lie in bed and watch The Day After Tomorrow on the computer. Sophie falls asleep first and Frances quietly puts the computer away. Frances makes a move out of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (eyes closed) Don’t be stupid.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I should sleep in my own bed.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Because I bought it.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Stay. But take off your socks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Okay...Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Shut up.  13

dialogues.speaker: PART ONE
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a photo of a bony, bug-eyed cat that resembles 1 an alien.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s hairless?

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, it has fine curly hair. CLOSE on Frances looking down. She looks up briefly, attempts a smile and looks back down. CLOSE on her hand touching the back of her neck. She stares at a photograph in her lap. She is wearing dance clothes underneath a knit dress, and her hair is pulled back. A bulky canvas backpack sits beside her. She’ll have it the whole film. CLOSE on her fingers smoothing the skin on her arm.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (excited) There’s this house in Westchester, the basement is all Cornish Rexes, it smells awful, the top floor is Siamese cats. She nods and hands Dan, early 30’s, back the photo. He sits opposite her on a thrift-store couch, a manilla envelope in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m allergic to cats.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: They're hypo-allergenic. (quick smile) This is a special Frances kitty.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh...who knew? He passes her back a photo.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: This one is the runt. Which is cheaper but I think is the best one anyway. I figured one runt and one regular?  Frances hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I put a hundred dollar down payment on each cat...or eighty for the runt and a hundred for the other one. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Why not get one cat?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: A cat needs a buddy. If you get one cat you need to get two cats.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I‘1l give you two hundred dollars to get no cats. He nods, somewhat hurt and annoyed, glances back at the photo of the runt, starts stacking the photos and tucking them back into the envelope. Frances comes over and sits next to him, puts her hand on his back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: So, who will take care of them if you go away?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I thought...we’d get them together.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: And move them back and forth between our apartments?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: No...I thought maybe you could move in with me... Frances hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (strangely) Oh, wow...

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Do you want to move in with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yes. (pause) I mean, I do have this other thing.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What “other thing?”

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Well...I don’t know. I promised Sophie I'd stay through the lease. He sighs deeply.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Is that bad? I’m sorry. I feel bad.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Can’t she find someone else?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah. But, it’s my friend...

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I want to move in with you.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I feel bad.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Don’t feel bad. Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... (off his expression) What?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You're mad.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I’m not mad. I’m disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I feel bad.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Stop feeling bad, Frances! I asked you to move in, you said, No. Her phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: But I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You can, you don’t want to. She looks at her phone. She does.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It’s okay, I don’t need to get it.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It’s Sophie. I’11 call her back.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Just pick up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone, a voice) Hey girl...waz up wid you? Where you at?...I can’t come now... (laugh) Are you drunk?...I can’t...I love you... Dan watches her without expression. He gets up and gets a beer from the fridge. She hangs He drinks

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (laughs) Dumpling house!...I love you...I can’t really talk now...I love you...Okay!...I love you. up and looks at him somewhat sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: She's with Benji and Lev at this party in Chinatown. (pause) They’re drunk. his beer.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know...maybe this isn’t working.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (a new idea) Maybe... (pause) Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I do want to pay you for the cats.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I’m not going to take money from you. But I’m going to get the cats anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then you’re going to be a single guy with two cats.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Why...why am I going to be single?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: With two cats.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: No, I know. I mean why would I be single?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I don’t know... I thought you said this wasn’t working. I mean, if we don’t move in together. If we can’t move in together.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: We can move in together.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I don’t know...I don’t know if I believe anything I’m saying.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Uh huh. (pause) This hasn’t been great for a while.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (nods ) This hasn’t been great for a while. This has not... She looks at him sadly. Frances puts on a too-big bomber jacket, not really cool, just something a friend gave her

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I guess home. I’m really tired. I’m always so tired. She puts on her backpack.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (sadly) Let’s move in together.  14 15 16 17 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Frances (wearing the same clothes). She walks through a crowd and leans in to Sophie. Sophie is talking to Benji and Lev. WIDER: They drink, dance in a silly way, laugh. Lev plays a record. He tries very hard to flirt with Frances.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I can't get interested in art or books or movies about animals. Animals in conversation. The animals have to talk or be at war for me to be interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one is on the platform. Frances pulls down her pants and pees into the tracks, holding onto the pillar to suspend her bare bottom out over the track. Sophie looks for a train. She turns to see--

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Don’t hit the third rail! Sophie’s attention goes to an MTA flyer posted.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Shit! The three’s not running!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances lying in Sophie’s lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances, in her same clothes, smokes a cigarette by the open window. Sophie, sleep-wear on, sits next to her with her legs propped up on the sill. Sophie extends her hand for the cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I want a sip.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Do you want your own?  11.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I want a sip. Frances reluctantly hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: The coffee people are right. We are like a lesbian couple that doesn’t have sex anymore. Sophie hands it back and exits frame.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Wait! Come back!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t pick at your face.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (kind of to herself, touching a pimple) I don’t like smoking alone. She puts out her own cigarette and follows Sophie to the bedroom. Sophie is writing an email on her phone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Me and Dan don’t have sex anymore...didn’t have sex anymore.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s why you broke up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Or if it happened then he would just - he only had one way that he could finish.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I hate that. 18 Sophie enters the bathroom. Washes her face. 18

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It was always with me facing flat on the bed from behind. Which just...everything that matters was covered up.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It’s like with me and Patch -  12.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (making fun) Yo Patchy!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (also making fun) ‘Sup bra? (continue, matter of fact) The way he always likes to come in my face.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah, CLASSY. Patch is the kind of dude who says “I gotta take a leak.”

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (cringing) And wears pre-distressed baseball hats. But...he’s a nice guy...for today. Frances joins Sophie in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I should feel bad that I went to the party.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You deserved it. You just got out of relationship jail.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I think Dan was an alcoholic.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: He was. Sophie leaves frame.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: He wasn’t a real alcoholic. Frances leaves frame.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: But sometimes he would have twelve beers. 19 Sophie lies in bed. She’s still typing on her phone. 1

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Stop playing on your phone.  13. Frances flops down into bed next to her.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It’s the only thing with interweb in this house. I have to answer work emails.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (to herself) The neighbors changed their code.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (re: her phone) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Lev is asking for your number.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Give it to him!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (not judgemental) You did just break up with Dan today.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Just do it. She types in the number. Frances gets her phone from a bag and stares at it. Waiting. Sophie goes back to typing on her phone. Frances’ phone chirps. Reads out loud.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: “Ahoy sexy. Are you around this week?” Ahoy sexy?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: That is actually very gay.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Am I nautically sensual?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You’re funny.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Lev didn’t laugh at any of my jokes tonight.  14.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You are SO funny.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Should I text back “Starboard anal sex?” Sophie laughs. Puts her phone down. Snuggles down in bed.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (settling) No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Tell me the story of us...

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Again? Well, Frances, we are going to take over the world...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: .+-You’ll be this awesomely bitchy publishing mogul...

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: ...And you’1ll be a famous modern dancer and I'll publish a really expensive book about you...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: ...That d-bags we make fun of buy to put on their coffee tables...

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: +.-and we co-own a vacation apartment in Paris...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: .-.and we will have lovers...

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: --.and no children...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: ..-and we will speak at college graduations...

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: ...and honorary degrees!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: ...SO many honorary degrees.  20 21 22 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie and Frances are asleep in the same bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances warms up alone in an empty studio. While holding a position, Frances notices a woman pass by the open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances pops her head into the outer office.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Hey! Colleen, 40’s, beautiful, retired dancer - drops everything she’s holding.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Sorry. I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: I don’t really have time to talk, I’m doing the job of three people here, but I can see you after rehearsal.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I read that article in the Times -- you must be so happy!

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, thanks, I forget I make my own work sometimes, but thanks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I usually hate that woman’s writing.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Right. Well, thank you Frances.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I actually, I had a couple of questions. I’m trying to be pro- active about my life.  16.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: (getting it) I’'ll see if I have some studio openings for choreography time --

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: -- Uh, no. I wanted to know if there were any more classes at the school that I could teach...I’ma little, I’m kind of broke.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: I’1l check, but I’m all full I think --

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: -- I thought so, I’m just proud of myself for asking.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Well, we’ll probably use you and some other apprentices for the Christmas show, so, that’s something.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: That’s GREAT. Frances just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I just wanted to say I really look up to you, and I just, I think you're great.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Ha! A beat-up old dancer doing paperwork? Frances still stands there a little goofily. Colleen decides to wrap it up:

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: I really need to do all that paperwork now - I’m running rehearsal today so I’ll see you in there.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Bye. Frances disappears.  23 24 25 26 27 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About twenty two dancers are rehearsing. Colleen runs the rehearsal. Frances is paired with Rachel, 25, about her height and build. They laugh and talk in between working.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Do you have more gum?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: What? No. (taking the gum out of her mouth) I don’t even know where this gum came from. Frances dances behind her, mirroring her movements. Other pairs of dancers do the same. Colleen claps her hands:

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Understudies, out! Frances and a few others go to the side and watch the primary company dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances teaches ballet to a group of young girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances shops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances goes uptown. Clutching two huge grocery bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances waits outside a building, watching people exit. She sees Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie and Frances eat. The park is almost deserted. It’s twilight and too cold for a picnic. They have pushed several tables together and made a banquet table and spread everything out. They toast two Pellegrino bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the subway. Sophie keeps checking her phone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: No service.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Sometimes there is, for a second...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: What is going on with that phone, lady?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to do it without knowing it was okay with you first.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (putting her phone away) I want to move into this apartment with Phoebe. It’s this great apartment in the West Village which is what I’ve always wanted and you know that but I don’t want to do it if you’re not okay with it --

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh --

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: But they need to know by tomorrow. So I kind of need to tell them something today...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Who have you been emailing?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: My parents, for help with the broker's fee and stuff. 28 29  Revision (05/14/2012) 19.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You have to pay OUR rent.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I know and I’1l pay until the end of the lease but it’s only for another two months anyway. Are you okay with it? I really don’t want to do it if you’re not okay with it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I sort of thought we were going to renew the lease.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but we never talked about it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I could have moved in with Dan.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Not if you broke up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: That’s why we broke up.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It’s LITERALLY on my favorite street. Phoebe said it was too good to pass up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You hate Phoebe.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: She’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: We make fun of her.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: She said I'd always regret it if I don't just go for it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Then go for it.  Revision (05/14/2012) 20.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: We're both really clean.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I said go for it.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I wish it was going to be with you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: But Phoebe found the place.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Is this train skipping DeKalb? She gets up to look at the subway map.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: We could look for another place together, if you want, but it’s really hard to find stuff in the West Village.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I can’t afford the West Village.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I know it’s so expensive. My raise just barely covers the rent.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You should take the place.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m not leaving you - I’m just moving neighborhoods. Frances’s eyes well up.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah. Totally. Frances is messing with her hand.  30 21.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I just put my ring on my thumb and I’m having trouble getting it off.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Hold your hand over your head. It‘’ll drain the blood out. Frances does.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I look like I’m asking a question.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m not doing anything wrong. Our lease was going to be up in two months anyway. They ride in silence, Frances’ hand over her head.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FRANCES AND SOPHIE'S APARTMENT. DAYS LATER. MORNING
dialogues.text: Frances gets a tea bag out and puts it in a mug. She rattles around the cabinets looking for a kettle. Not finding a kettle, she boils water in a saucepan. While she’s waiting for the water to boil, she lights a cigarette. The apartment is nearly empty. It turns out Sophie had most of the furniture and Frances had most of the books. It looks like the crack den of a pretty well educated junkie. The water boils. Frances tries to pour it into the mug, but scalds herself. She kicks the kitchen cabinet. Frances is on the phone. She moves.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (on the phone) We bought the kettle TOGETHER! REMEMBER? At the Mexican superstore? Jesus! BRING IT BACK. OR BUY ME ANOTHER KETTLE.  31 32 33 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mailbox. Frances is checking the mail. Sees something she likes. Tax rebate! Whoops and runs out onto the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances leaves the bank. Is still elated. Looks around, unsure what to do next. Her elation leaves her slightly. She pulls out her phone and scrolls. Half shrugs, calls someone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Hey I just got a tax rebate, want to go out to dinner?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lev (from the party) is scrolling through his phone. He finds the photo he was looking for and hands the phone to Frances across the table.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: This is me in the locker room of the Knicks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Wow!

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Sophie said you liked basketball.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: That was just one time. Frances changes the picture.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Wow! Crazy!

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: (looking at the picture) Oh, yeah, I was goofing around on this Vintage Triumph I think I’m going to buy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Motorcycles are so loud.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, you can’t listen to music while you’re on a motorcycle.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: But you’re on a motorcycle. Lev takes back his phone, finds a new picture.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Check it. This is me with Jay Leno.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: He’s such a dick.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: I know, but don’t you just love him? The waitress comes up to give them the check. Frances grabs it and puts her credit card in.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: No...I mean, YES! I’m the one with the tax rebate!

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Can I take this?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Oh...fine. The waitress leaves.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Just because you bought dinner doesn’t mean I’m going to sleep with you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (not getting it) I’m not trying to sleep with you...  24.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: No, I’m pretending to be a liberated woman.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, got it.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Thanks for paying. That was very sweet. You’re a lady. He takes her hand. She lets him. The waitress comes back. Frances immediately withdraws her hand.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but the card didn’t go through, do you have another card you want to try?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, shit! Sorry, yes, um, this is a debit card?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Only credit cards or cash.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Okay. (to Lev) I’m so embarrassed, I’m not a real person yet.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (getting up from the table) No, no, no, I’m just going to go run and get some cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances hustles down the street, looking for an ATM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances runs in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Where is your ATM?

dialogues.speaker: DELI GUY
dialogues.text: Not working. No ATM.  36 37 38 39 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks for a bank or something. She stops a woman.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Do you know where a bank is?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Um, there’s a Bank of America about five blocks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances punches in her pin in the ATM area of a closed B of A while a homeless man looks on. “Do you accept the $3.00 service charge?” She sighs, her finger hovering over the button, accepts. As she passes the homeless guy:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances runs back to the restaurant. Falls. Hard. Gets up and keeps running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The restaurant is considerably more cleared out. Frances has been gone a long time. She sits down plunks the money down, happy. Lev is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: I’1ll ask her and let you know...okay, man, see you. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Sorry, that was Benji. You know, my Sophie. Frances is flushed and out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: You go to Switzerland?  40 26.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (breathing heavy) Have I been to Switzerland? No.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: No, did you go to -- I mean, where were you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I had so much trouble finding -- She casually picks up the last bit of her wine and downs it. She puts her glass down, and wipes at her face with the napkin. She looks at the napkin, it has streaks of red.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: What the fuck? She tries to trace the blood up her arm to its source.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: You're bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I can’t find it.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Somewhere on your arm... She feels her arm, trying to figure it out. Her elbow.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Shit. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Don’t apologize to me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, damn it. Oh, let me, I’m going to go to the bathroom, just one second. INT. LEV AND BENJI’S APARTMENT. NIGHT. 40 Frances stands in their apartment. Totally enamored with it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: This place is pretty awesome. Lev enters with a First Aid Kit.  27.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: I’m a First Responder.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You didn’t have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: (opening the Bandaid) You're injured.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I know, but I’m fine. He places the bandage on her arm.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Like a boy scout... Sophie makes fun of me because I can’t account for my bruises. We’re not living together anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m going to have to find a place to live. I can’t afford to stay there alone. I was kind of thinking Washington Heights...?

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: (lighting a cigarette) The chick crashing in the little room might be moving to Portland next month.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s good to know. (then) You smoke inside?

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Yeah, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Want to?  4l 42 28. He offers her a cigarette. Lights it for her with a special lighter.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: This makes me feel like a bad mother in 1987.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Wanna see my room? INT. LEV’S ROOM. MOMENTS LATER. 41 Frances is looking at the framed pictures on the wall. They are old and yellowed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Is this your family?

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Nope. They are quiet a little too long. Lev moves towards her and puts his hand on her shoulder. Frances glances at the hand, and instantly makes a face and a strange noise that is definitely negative. It’s something that if she had thought about for one second more that she wouldn’t have done. Lev moves away. They hear Benji come through the door. He has two girls with him. They make a lot of noise.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOM GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh my GOD! This place is AMAZING!

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Benji’s home. INT. LEV AND BENJI’S APARTMENT. LIVING ROOM. A LITTLE 42 LATER. One girl dances to music. Lev plays cribbage with another girl. Flirting heavily with her - looking at her cards, teasing her. Benji and Frances are talking. Frances drinks a scotch out of a proper scotch glass.  29.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I love dance. I dated a dancer in high school and her teacher said I could have really had a future in it.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: (joking but serious) You liar. He’s a liar.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: No I’m not! Ask anyone from school! (to Frances) I really to love dance.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It’s pretty great...I mean it’s a hard world, but -

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Do us a dance!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I feel weird...

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Just one move. Frances gets up does something quickly and sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: That was GREAT!

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: You should be in this music video my friend is working on. I‘'11 hook you guys up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (to herself) You guys are...like magic.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Is Noodle Champion still open? I’m starving.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: I don’t think so...

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: All we have is...we have eggs. I want something PREPARED. And BROUGHT to me.  43 44 45 46

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Wait! INT. LEV AND BENJI’S APARTMENT. KITCHEN. LATER Frances has the stove going with a couple of items. INT. LEV AND BENJI’S APARTMENT. LIVING ROOM. LATER Frances serves everyone omelettes prettily. People compliment her and the food.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It’s Sophie’s recipe, but... She does a little twirl of happiness. INT. LEV AND BENJI’S APARTMENT. LIVING ROOM. LATER. The other two girls leave. Kiss everyone on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: (to his girl) I’1l call you. We’1l shoot some pigeons.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: And I‘1l1 let you know about my show.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOM GIRL
dialogues.text: Yes! Please! I love your hair.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Thanks. Everyone’s gone, Frances moves to the couch between Lev and Benji.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: This is the best night I’ve had since Sophie dumped me. She basks in it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (nods, half-hearted) I should probably go, too.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Make a left and a left out of the building and the F is on the other side of the bridge on East Broadway. 30. 43 44 45 46  Revision (05/14/2012)

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: You'll see a 99 Cent Store --

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Okay, yeah. I should go. (beat, indicating the extra room) Is that chick really moving to Portland?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Before you go, do another dance.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (this time eager) Ok! She gets up and starts to dance. The boys love it. 31.  47 48 49 50 32.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHINATOWN. DUSK.
dialogues.text: Music swells. Frances runs through the streets of Chinatown, bomber jacket and backpack on. She’s running, almost dancing through the streets. She bursts into the apartment. INT. BEDROOM. NIGHT. Frances is asleep. She hears people having sex. She opens her eyes, stirs. Closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The two boys, Benji and Lev, run into the bedroom and jump on top of her bed, play-tickling her and body slamming her. It’s morning.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN TABLE. LATER
dialogues.text: Benji on his computer, smoking a cigarette. Still in a T- shirt and pajama bottoms. Frances on her computer, backpack on, ready to leave. Both drinking Folgers instant coffee.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: What time did you get in last night?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Um, late. Like 1:00.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you come in and say hi?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry -- I thought you were asleep.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I wasn’t asleep. I heard you come in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Then you knew what time I got in?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: (ignoring her question) I’m working on some sample skits for Saturday Night Live. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BENJI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know a producer there who said I could probably get a job writing for them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: That’s such a lie. Lev has come out of his room. Fully dressed, bare feet. A girl, Nessa, trails after him. She’s about twenty. Very thin. Not wearing pants, just underwear and a big t- shirt.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Guys. This is Nessa.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (putting out her hand to shake) Hello. I’m Frances.

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: Lev and I were going to make bacon egg bagels. You want some?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Thanks though. I wanted to go to the Met and drop this laundry off and I need to deposit a check, a whole...Sunday planned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances eats a very large egg bagel very quickly. So quickly that she nearly chokes. Her backpack is now off. She notices how much faster she’s eating than everyone else. Slows down. Or tries to.

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: Why do you all live together?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Well, I knew Benji through Sophie and -

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Where is Sophie these days?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Busy with work.  34.

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: Which Sophie?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Sophie Kozak?

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: Get out! I fucked her little brother!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, you fucked Thomas?

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: You fucked who?

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: (to Frances) How do you know her?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: We went to college together and we're...we were born together.

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: Oh you’re that Frances.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Who is Thomas?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Not really but that’s what we say. (beat) Yeah, I’m that Frances.

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: You should know she speaks so highly of you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Right. I mean, we're best friends. She’s been to my house for Christmas three times.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Why doesn’t she go to her house?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (annoyed) She’s Jewish.

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: She was saying last week how much she loves you.  35.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You saw her last week?

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: When did you fuck her brother?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Where were you guys?

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: (to Lev) I met you last night. (then to Frances) We were at that restaurant Po.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Who were you fucking last week, Lev?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: What...is that a good restaurant? Was she with...who was she with?

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: Me and Thomas and that guy she dates, Patch?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Double date.

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: And some girl. Esme.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Phoebe. Cunt.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Who were you fucking last week Frances?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (joking) I make love.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Frances: UNDATEABLE! Nessa is thinking about something. Puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Aren’t you a lot older than Sophie?  52 36.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: No. We went to college together.

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: You seem older.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m a couple months older.

dialogues.speaker: NESSA
dialogues.text: You seem a LOT older. But less, like, grown up. It’s weird. You have an older face...

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: .--but like you don’t have your shit together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances lays on the couch, shoes off. Benji still on the computer. Lev is standing by the door, holding a motorcycle helmet.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: (a little sadly) Nessa can’t come from sex. Only sixty-nine.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: That’s a crazy helmet.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Got to. Motorcycle law. Oh, can you leave that rent check for me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, sorry. I'll put it on your desk. It’s for...$950?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I...I don’t, I thought we said $950 when I moved in.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Nope. The whole space is $4000 but the little room is only $1200

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: But, I --  37.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: No, she’s right. We said she could pay that much until she got more cash together.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Remember because when I do the Christmas show I’11 make more because I’1l be doing like ten shows a week...

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Oh right right.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: So we're good with $950? That’s okay? I’m really sorry... He puts down his motorcycle visor.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: No prob. Catch you on the flipside! Lev leaves.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: He leaves so easily...

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Transportation is his thing. Bike, skateboard. He has a car, too.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I can’t even get out of the house on my feet! She is quietly dejected.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You know what Virginia Woolf book this reminds me of?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Frances: UNDATEABLE. Frances laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Wanna watch a movie?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Now?  38.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Yeah, let’s do a movie afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I already wasted the whole day - I already feel bad about the day.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I think it’s a great day. I ate an egg bagel that Lev’s slut made me. I internet acquired three pairs of very rare Ray Bans. I’m doing awesome.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I thought we were both broke!

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I caved and finally took a loan from my step dad. Bastard. I need a fucking job, though.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: What about SNL?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe. It’s gone so downhill. Goes to the bar. Looks at his watch. Pours himself a scotch.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Until then, it’s after three. I can drink. Let’s do something fun. We could go to a movie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Movies are so expensive now...I should be saving so I can pay full rent.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I’m not going to force you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (getting up, ready) I have to work out, at least. I cannot get fat. Frances puts on shoes, etc. Benji drinks his scotch and starts going through his records to pick one.  53 54 39.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Do I look old to you?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: No. Yes. How old?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Older than I am? Older than twenty- seven?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: No. Twenty-seven is old, though. CUT TO: It’s dark out. Benji and Frances watch a movie. 5 Benji smokes and eats an egg roll. Frances wolfs down a box of General Tso’s Chicken. She realizes she’s eating too fast - tries to slow down. INT. BOY’S APARTMENT. NEW DAY 54 Sophie looks at the stuff. Frances bobs next to her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Isn't this place AMAZING?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Is that an Eames chair?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah, isn’t this GREAT?!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Total rich-kid apartment.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: The boys just have good eyes. They find stuff all the time.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Do you know who Lev Shapiro’s dad is?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: He doesn’t get along with his dad...Lev and Benji are artists.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Exactly -- the only people who can afford to be artists in New York are rich.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m an artist. I’m not rich.  40.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You are rare. (beat) It’s just this apartment is very...aware of itself.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (defensively) Everyone who comes here loves it. I love it. The three of us are hilarious together. We're like a sitcom. My Two Husbands.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (softening) No, that sounds great. I’m really happy for you, Frances.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (a tad bitchy) Thank you, Sophie. Sophie sits beside her on the couch. Puts her head on Frances’s shoulder. Lev comes through the door.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Ladies!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Lev Shapiro! You know Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Of course. Still beautiful. Kisses her hand. Sophie giggles. Frances looks thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: How is the publishing business?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You know. Not good. How’s sculpture?

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Amazing.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Oh my boyfriend likes that artist you work for...  41.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Tell your boyfriend he can always talk to me if he wants to buy something.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (to herself) Are we buying art now? Is that the point we’re at?

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: I need to clean up. Ladies.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Bye! Lev retreats into his bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Lev would totally date you.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I have a boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: But isn’t he charming? And so handsome? You could be over here all the time, it would be GREAT. You wouldn’t have to spend all that time with Phoebe.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (laughs) Right, I could fuck him just to not hang out with Phoebe! Lev walks across the living room in just a towel.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Don’t mind me. I’m just trying to get your attention. Lev goes into the bathroom. The shower turns on.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: How could you not want to date him? He’s kind of magic.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Because I’m with Patch.  42.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Patch is the kind of guy who buys a black leather couch and is like “I love it.” Sophie doesn’t react. Frances gets up. Starts trying to do a headstand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: What are we doing with our day?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I have to get going around five, so I guess I should leave at --

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I thought we were hanging out.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: We are.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: All day.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I have plans with Patch tonight. I told you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I don’t remember that.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I texted that to you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: No you didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yes I did. Here -- Sophie gets out her phone, starts scrolling.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: We're not doing that. That’s shitty. It’s not court.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I did text you, though.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I believe you.  55 43.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to believe me, I did text you. She holds out her phone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Do you want to see my room? INT. FRANCES’S ROOM 55 Sophie and Frances in her room. They flop down on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I kind of have a crush on this boy, but his name is Georgie so I don’t know how far it’s going to go.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Can't fuck a Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: “I want you inside me Georgie.”

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Have you been dating anyone?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Frances.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: What about Benji?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Benji thinks I’m undateable. It’s really funny when he does it. (indicating her and Sophie) You and I are both undateable. Guys can’t handle us. We are going to be spinsters.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Better break that to Patch.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Boys are easier. Girls are passive aggressive, boys are just like “clean up your shit.”

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (looking around) You're still messy...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’ve been busy.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: No, it wasn’t a criticism, I meant it in a nice way. You will always be messy and you will always look at yourself too much in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: When do I look at myself in the mirror?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Always -- you just were doing it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: There are so many mirrors in this apartment!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to change. I like your clothes everywhere and your mirror thing -- it’s sweet.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You have stuff, too.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You judge people who aren’t as moderate as you are.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I do not.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yes you do. And you don’t read. Just then, Benji comes running into the room and leaps into bed with them.  56 57 58 45.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Hey bitches!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh my God, Benji! You're crazy! CUT TO: It’s night. Benji and Frances watch a movie. 56

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (suddenly) I wish we had cookies. (pause) I wish we had Chessmen. The front door opens. Lev and a dark haired, long legged girl enter. Different girl than Nessa.

dialogues.speaker: LEV
dialogues.text: Hey guys. (to girl) Wanna see my room? They walk in front of the TV and into his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances performs in a piece with a troupe. She’s in the back, but she’s in it. She is really, really dancing her heart out. Very happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances is one of the last ones to get her stuff out. Colleen comes in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Sorry! I’m so slow! I have trouble leaving places!

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: You looked great tonight.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Thanks!

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Frances, I wanted to tell you so you had some days to process it - we won’t be able to use you in the Christmas show. I’m really sorry.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry -- you know what bad shape the company is in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (tearing up) I know.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: (gently) We can talk about next steps when we're back in February.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Am I fired?

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: No! I just, I like you and I want to talk to you about the future and make sure it’s what you want.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I want to be in the company.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: I know. Frances is crushed.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Take your time.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah. I will. I can’t help it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances walks across the deserted stage. Takes a self- consciously sad moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most people are gone. A few stragglers remain. Frances sees Sophie. Runs to her, hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (thrilled) Oh, my love, I’m so glad you’re here!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You were great, really great.  47.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Could you see me?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we were on the risers, so we could see to the back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Who? Patch walks up.

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: Sorry, I had to take a leak. Congratulations! Frances face hardens.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Thank you. Patch doesn’t pick up on anything.

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: Should we all go out for a quick drink?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: A “quick” drink?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: We have to get up early tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Tomorrow is Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: We have to catch a flight in the morning -- we’re meeting my parents in the Galapagos.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (trying to connect to Frances) I haven’t packed. You know me.

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: Last Minute Mabel.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Ronald Rule Follower. They are doing a routine. He does this weird kind of strangle motion and she acts like she’s getting strangled. Frances just stares at them.  61 62 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances, Patch and Sophie sit in a corner. It’s kind of a douche-y club/bar. The waitress comes up.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’ll have a glass of --

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: -- We’ll get a bottle of your most expensive vodka for the table. And then all the stuff that comes with it.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Very good. She leaves. Patch laughs and rubs his hands together uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances is doing shots. Patch and Sophie sip on their drinks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (very drunk) I want us to be a family, you know? I can be part of your family, don’t you think? Patch I love you. I want to love you. But I need you to get drunk. The waitress comes back.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: How are we doing over here.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: We're good. Bring the check, we'll finish the bottle. Sophie?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Sophie come with me.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Where?  63 49.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Really? Are we still doing this? Frances is pulling Sophie away.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Patch, you got this?

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: Um, yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances and Sophie inside a stall together. Frances sits on the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I was lying. I don’t love Patch.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I do love him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Since when? When did this happen?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It’s been happening.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: That’s fucking BULLSHIT. SOPHIE. COME ON.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: No, you're bullshit. And you're making me feel really bad right now.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I want to love him if you love him but you don’t love him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (tearing up) SOPHIE. I fucking held your head when you cried I bought special milk for you I know where you hide your pills do not treat me like a three hour brunch friend.  64 50.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m not talking to you while you’re like this. Frances hits the wall close to Sophie’s head. It’s violent and kind of scary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie two steps ahead of Frances, rushing back to the table. She starts gathering her things. So does Frances.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (to Patch) We have to go.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m going.

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: (to Sophie) We can stay if you want.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’M GOING.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (to Patch) C’mon, get your stuff. Frances gets angry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: NO I’M GOING. YOU FUCKING SIT DOWN. They sit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (putting on a act) Enjoy the Galapagos. I am also going on a vacation. A long one. I‘1l set up my email so it sends out a vacation email. And my voicemail will also say I’m on vacation. So if you get that, Sophie, don’t worry, I’m ona vacation. I’ll try to give you a call when I get back, okay? Thanks, guys. This was great. Frances shoves the bottle of vodka into her purse and takes off.  65 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bottle of vodka that Frances took is sitting on her dresser. All the lights are on. Frances is visibly upset. She is putting away all the clothes in her room, trying to straighten up, make a neatness. She looks at herself in the mirror for one second, catches herself doing it, and looks away. Benji appears in the door watching her.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: You're cleaning!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (defensively) I’m not messy, I’m busy! Benji is inside the room. He sits on the bed. Frances looks at it, discouraged.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I don’t make my bed. Sophie always made the bed. She keeps cleaning.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m glad you’re home. I had a shitty night.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Sorry kid. I had a great night. I cracked the second act of my script. I’m on page 68.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: That's exciting. Is that for SNL?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: No, this is s sample script I’m writing for the fourth Beverly Hills Cop. (smiles) Boy trouble tonight?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Sophie trouble...

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Undateable.  52.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: And I kind of, I don’t know, I got temporarily fired.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I’ve been fired like a million times! It makes you cool!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (dejected) Yeah. But without the Christmas show, I can’t pay... (then) Do you have any good tunes?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: (clearly pleased) Wait right there! He gets his iPod and big headphones. He puts them on her.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: It’s a jammer.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (too loudly) It's great.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I know. He does that thing where he looks at her too intensely while she’s listening, trying to figure out what part of the song she’s on. She takes them off.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I love it. Put it on my mix. He puts the headphones back on, wanting her to listen to the song.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Aren’t these headphones tits? I just got them. They’re super-duper noise cancelling. So I don’t have to hear Lev fuck. She takes them off again--

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Ha. --he tries to push them back on, she shoves them back to him and goes back to cleaning.  53.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Lev and I were talking about getting a maid to come in once a week.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: A maid?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s not that expensive, like $400 bucks a month? Frances cleans drunkenly, thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Do you know that I’m actually poor?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: You aren’t poor. There are poor people. You aren’t one of them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yes, but it’s, I mean, you’d feel poor if you had as little money as I do.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: But you’re not poor. That’s offensive to actual poor people.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess that’s true. Frances keeps cleaning. Benji considers something.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: You want -- you want to hear something hilarious?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Lev thinks we’re going to end up married.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m too tall to marry.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Ha! You are.  54.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: That’s so funny. Why would he think that?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I did want to sleep with you when I first met you. (quickly) But now - totally undateable!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I guess we are like a married couple in a way. We talk. We don’t have sex.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Yeah. We get along super well.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Sophie and I used to be like that, too.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: But Sophie was a girl. And you were both straight. So it had less, like, real world probability. Frances yawns.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Right. Of course. Well. I’m done. I hope I don’t have the spins when I lay down.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Just lay on your back by the edge of the bed and put one foot on the floor. It helps. Frances nods. Benji reluctantly gets off the bed.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Goodnight, then.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Night. Good luck with Beverly Hills Cop.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Four. Benji walks towards the door.  55.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Open? Shut?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Um, shut. I think. I don’t know. Does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I‘1l leave it open so if you need to throw up or cry or something you can call me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Thanks. Yeah. Open. He’s gone. Frances sits down on the bed. She looks towards the mirror and self-indulgently stares at herself.  66 67 68 69 70 71 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office is vaguely Christmas-y, maybe a wreath somewhe Frances walks down the hallway, a creepy long hallway wit lot of people’s stuff behind metal. She is carrying a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances stands on the corner with the chair. It’s cold ou A student-looking person walks by. Frances approaches her with the chair. The student rejects the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances sits on the chair and writes something on a piece card board. Gets up and puts the cardboard paper on it. I reads: Free Chair. Totally normal, really. Didn't fit in storage space. Needs a home.

dialogues.speaker: SACRAMENTO
dialogues.text: The following moments occur as silent scenes of a Sacrame Christmas. The audio playing over all the shots in this sequence is a conversation that Frances is having with he mother while driving in a car around Sacramento. (Found audio). INT. SACRAMENTO INT’L AIRPORT. DAY. 69 Frances comes down an escalator, sees her parents waiting her, holding a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances’ modest childhood home, decorated with lights for Christmas. A tree in the window. Also all lit up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances and her parents attend a Sunday service at the Unitarian Universalist Society. The UU Society is really like a multi-purpose cafeteria type of room with fold out chairs and hippie-ish banners.  72 73 74 75 76 77 78 79 80 57. Frances going around with her parents and shaking the han of older people she used to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances rides her bike through the streets of Sacramento.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances lies in the tub, not moving, eyes closed. The bathroom is decorated and kind of falling apart. The pain peeling around the sink, but all the towels match. Christ towels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances and her parents walk along a special street in Sacramento that has TONS of Christmas lights and decorati

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas “dinner” - really late lunch: About twenty peop crammed around a table. The table doesn’t quite fit every so there is a card table set up as an extension. Frances’ is carving and serving. Frances gets happy drunk. There a so many people and so much happiness that the windows fog

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances’ and her Dad walk the dog on the levee along the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances’ Dad takes down the Christmas lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances’ helps her Mom pack away ornaments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances sits in the back of the car with her Mom and Dad the front, the dog in her lap. INT. SACRAMENTO INT’L AIRPORT. DAY. 80 Frances checks in, hugs her parents. As she rides up the escalator away from them, she starts to cry. She cries al the way through security and onto the plane. END SACRAMENTO MONTAGE.  58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances is carrying a sleeping bag and a rolling suitcase her backpack.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Stop thanking me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It just means a lot, letting me stay with you-- I want you to know. You will definitely be getting a thank-you note. Remind me to get your address in my e-mail.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It’s the only thing that’s forever. E-mail. They walk along in silence.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Hey! Have you ever done--where you sing and--the other... It’s easier to just do it, okay? You sing, make up some songs about whatever, and I’1l dance...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh for money, kind of, so if you see someone then just shout “GIVE ME YOUR MONEY!”

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I don’t want to.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I‘1l sing and you dance, if you want.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: We don’t need money like that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It’s not for money. I think it’s good to feel stupid sometimes. Did you see that movie, Once?  59.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I've worked in homeless shelters and it’s not funny to make fun of people who have to beg and panhandle.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Panhandle sounds old fashioned. Rachel looks annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m not making fun. Just watch me do it for a second. Frances launches into singing and dancing while Rachel ju stands there. Someone walks by and Frances screams:

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (staring) This is making me very uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (suddenly stops) It’s stupid. Sorry. They walk along again in silence.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Do you want to put on really fancy clothes and then go steal stuff from Sephora? Rachel says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Sorry about that. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You’re welcome.

dialogues.speaker: NADIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh my God, she’s like the most beautiful creature! 82 INT. SOME COUPLE’S APARTMENT. NIGHT. 82 CLOSE on a picture of a baby on an iPhone. Nadia passes the iPhone to Spencer.  60.

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Wow. That’s a healthy little girl. It’s a six person dinner party. Spencer and Nadia, 30's, Janelle, and Andy, 40’s, Rachel and Frances. Frances is under-dressed, wearing her jacket, backpack. S awkwardly sits at the head of the table.

dialogues.speaker: JANELLE
dialogues.text: She's in the 90 percentile for height and 95 for weight.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: But it evens out later. When they walk. It doesn’t mean she’1l be fat. Spencer hands it to Frances. She fiddles around on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, I think you're getting a call. She hands the phone to Andy who checks it and puts it in pocket.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It’s so funny when people have kids and they’re all “I used to be so focussed on ‘me’ and now I’m totally not” - it’s like, NO! It’s still you. It’s a mini you! It’s a half you! I mean, you made it! (eating too fast) I forgot to eat today. Pockets of conversation:

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: The only time you ever hear the phrase “I’m not here to make friends” is on reality television. Andy starts to pour Frances wine. She puts her hand over glass, some splashing on her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Oh...sorry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m trying not to drink right now.  Revision (05/14/2012) 61.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Don’t be sorry. You’re not the one who's bat-shit crazy after four vodkas.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Yeah...Nadia had a hard time giving it up while she was pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: “What do you do?” It’s such a stupid question I thought I’d ask it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m a lawyer. What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: What a stupid question! Just kidding...it’s, it’s hard to explain.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Because what you do is complicated?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: No...because I don’t really do it? Suddenly all conversation has stopped and everyone has tu to Frances.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Well, I’m a dancer, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Frances and I are in the same company.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: But Rachel’s in the main company. I’m an apprentice. Hopefully the touring company soon. (to Rachel) I have a meeting with Colleen on Monday morning.  Revision (05/14/2012) 62.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (to the table, rambling) But I’m doing really good. Rachel and I have a really cool place. Or Rachel does and I’m staying there for six-ish weeks.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Five.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Right. Five. I’ve been running a lot. I think I might be training for the marathon.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Really? People react positively: Oh! Cool!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: But, yeah, everything is up in the air. I like being alone. I just got back from Sacramento.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Andy and Janelle just got back from Paris.

dialogues.speaker: JANELLE
dialogues.text: Six and half hours on a plane with a baby. Won’t be doing that again soon! But it was heaven.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (to Frances) Do you ever get to Paris?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Not really. No. Kind of once. Actually, no. What’s that museum with the escalators in tubes?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: The Pompidou.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah! (beat) Um, do you get there?  63.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: They have a great place in the 6th.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It’s a little pied a terre.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Literally!

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: --but it’s a really special place.

dialogues.speaker: JANELLE
dialogues.text: It’s just been so hard to spend any time there since I got the job at the Journal. (beat) And the baby.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I'd love to go to Paris. I'’11 bet it’s magic. One of my friends from college, Abby, who moved there because her boyfriend works for a bank. In school, she was on of the top five friends, but then Zoe became closer to our friend group and Abby kind of moved to the outer ring. Everyone at the table listens politely. Rachel could give two shits. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Sophie and Abby never totally got along. She started dating Luke who I always thought would have dated any of us, but he ended up with Abby.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Well, let me know if you’re ever there, we like for it to be used.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh okay...I don’t see myself probably getting there super soon, but...thanks, thanks.  Revision (05/14/2012) 64.

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Frances, I think you know one of my colleagues at Goldman, Reade “Patch” Krause.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I know Patch! ‘Sup bra?

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Mm. Yes, Patch knows more about South American currency stability than almost anyone else I know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: His girlfriend Sophie and I are the same person with different hair. Not really. We went to college together and took the train into the city on weekends and made bad decisions.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You got pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: No. What? No!

dialogues.speaker: NADIA
dialogues.text: She's a great lady. I really like her. So smart.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean, yeah. I mean, we're all smart.

dialogues.speaker: NADIA
dialogues.text: But she’s like book-smart, smart.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: She’s actually not. She doesn’t really read. I mean except for work which is the funny thing.

dialogues.speaker: NADIA
dialogues.text: She seems like she reads a lot to me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I read way more.

dialogues.speaker: NADIA
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Frances hesitates, hating herself in this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I don’t know why I’m shit-talking Sophie. She’s basically the best person I know.

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Crazy, though, right?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah. Which thing?

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Japan.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Japan?

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: They're moving to Japan in a couple of weeks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Patch got transferred. It’s a really cool position. TK.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: For how long?

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Indefinite.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: But Sophie has a job at Random House.

dialogues.speaker: NADIA
dialogues.text: She quit. CLOSE on Frances’ face as it changes, pained and sad and everything bad all at once. Conversation turns to other things, travel plans, airlines, food. Frances reaches for the wine and pours herself a steep gl

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: People have moved from the table and are now on the 83 terrace. Frances smokes. She’s drunk. She talks to Nadia.  Revision (05/14/2012) 66.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Nadia, I want this one moment...it’s what I want ina relationship, which might explain why I’m single now ha ha. It’s hard to...it’s like that thing where you are with someone and you love them and they know it, and they love you and you know it but it’s a party and you're both talking to other people and laughing and shining and you look across the room and catch each other’s eye not because you are possessive or that it’s precisely sexual but because that is your person in this life. And it’s funny and sad, but only because this life will end, and it’s a secret world that no one else knows about that exists right there in public unnoticed - sort of like how they say other dimensions exist all around us but we don’t have the ability to perceive them. That’s...that’s what I want out of a relationship. Or just life, I guess. Love. Blah, I sound stoned. I’m not stoned. (suddenly) Thanks for dinner. Bye!

dialogues.speaker: NADIA
dialogues.text: Oh...bye. Frances grabs her backpack. Rachel catches her.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Where the fuck are you going?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m kind of wasted. I was going to go home. Is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I don’t care, I was just kidding.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (pause, to the group) Thanks for inviting me tonight.

dialogues.speaker: JANELLE
dialogues.text: Nice to have met you.  84 Revision (05/14/2012) 67.

dialogues.speaker: SPENCER
dialogues.text: Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Hey, Andy, actually, I think I might be going to Paris this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Oh... (pause) Do you want to stay in our apartment?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
