dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Okay. Wonderful. I’11 get you the information.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Wonderful. Rachel is staring at her oddly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances walks. It’s cold. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Frances?! Frances turns around. It’s Benji. With a girl.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: I knew it was you! Your weird man walk.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (to the girl) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: This is Caroline.  Revision (05/14/2012) 68.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: I’m Caroline.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: How are the dances, Frances? Frances laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: (to Caroline) * Frances and I used to be married. *

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Cool. *

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: What are you guys doing? Want to get a drink?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: We're going to my friend’s party - it’s a house party. I mean, that’s the theme.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: How is that a theme?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Amazing, right?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: And it’s in an apartment. (beat) You can come with us. If you want. Frances considers for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: No...I really. I shouldn’t. I’m going to Paris this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Good for you, kid. (probably lying) I lived there for like a year.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: You never told me that.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Yep. I was there when Serge *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gainsbourg died. It was a crazy time? *  Revision (05/14/2012) 69.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: In 1991? When you were eight?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was the end of Euro-disco.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I have so much to do. I think I’11 read Proust because sometimes you should do what you’re supposed to do when you’re supposed to do it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Proust is pretty heavy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it’s worth it, I hear.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: No, I mean the book. Carrying it on the plane.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I should probably learn French first and read it in French. (beat) Undateable!

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Mm. Benji smiles warmly.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Well, kid. We’ve got to run.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You, too. You’re very pretty.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Thank you?

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: See you around, weirdo. He ruffles her hair. He and Caroline take each other’s ha and walk off. Frances feels odd - not jealous, exactly, b confused.  Revision (05/14/2012) 70. 85 INT. RACHEL’S APARTMENT. NIGHT Frances is sitting in the dark, on Rachel’s computer, concentrating. Key in the door, light on, Rachel walks in

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Is that my computer?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Mine’s so old it doesn’t have the wireless thing and Sophie always had one that worked and -

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: - Yes, you can use it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: There are some good fares.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I thought you couldn’t pay me rent.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I can’t. I have no cash. I’m putting in on this credit card I got in the mail.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: That’s not smart. That’s what they want. They want to keep you in debt.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I know that. I see documentaries. Hey! Do you want to come?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I travel with the company, it’s enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: So today is, what? Wednesday...I can go for a week! Oh no, shit. I have that meeting with Colleen on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Well...it’s not worth it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Andy’s already emailed me the information. And I took the virtual tour of the apartment.  86 87 88

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (re: computer) HEY LOOK! It’s perfect! The cheapest one and I get back in time for my meeting.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It’s still not worth it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It’s meant to be!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What’s that about anyway?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I don’t know, but she’s never asked me to have a meeting before... Silence.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You never know what could happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances exits having bought a book. Proust!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances looks out the window at Queens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances waits to board.

dialogues.speaker: INT. AIRPLANE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Frances tries to find the right jack in the seat for her headphones. Frances tries to sleep. 89B Frances reads Proust while everyone else sleeps. 89C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances rides in the back. She looks exhausted. She leave a message:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Hi, Abby, it’s Frances. I just got in. I’m going to this free apartment this dude owns now. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m here all of tomorrow. Call me...I’d love to see you and Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances searches around a flower pot. She lifts up a coup of small rocks. Under a bigger rock: the key! Frances opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances enters. It’s small, but very nice. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The clock reads 11:40. Frances lies in bed. 93A Frances shifts around in the bed. She can’t sleep. 93B Frances reads Proust. 93C The clock reads 3:56. Frances moves around more in bed, 9 trying to get comfortable. 5:04. She turns on a light. She enters the bathroom, 93E goes through her bag and gets a pill. Takes it. Light streams through the curtains. Frances sleeps like 9 a rock. The clock reads: 4:32. Frances opens her eyes. She 93G looks at the clock. It’s the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances tries to figure out the weird shower. She gets a small trickle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances tries to brush her hair quickly and then gets hun on a zit on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances wanders, hair still wet. It’s already getting dar She stops at a cute boutique. Is about to go in but the woman shakes her head. They’re closing.  97 73. She leaves another message:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Do you guys want to meet for dinner? I can meet you anywhere. I‘1ll be the girl with the acne holding more acne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances eats something lame and disgusting. Her phone rin It’s a Blocked number. Frances practically lunges for it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (breathless) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Frances?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (thrilled) Sophie?! Oh my god, hi!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (flat) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (anticipatory) Hil

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I called you because I wanted to tell you...that I’m moving to Japan with Patch.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh... Is that good? Are you excited?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I know things are weird between us, but we’re having a kind of going away party tonight and I wanted to say you're invited.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I’m...I’m...I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to lie.  Revision (05/14/2012) 74.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (genuine) No, I’m not lying. I’m not. That’s really awesome about Japan.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (softening) It’s CRAZY. Last week, Patch’s boss just called Patch into his office and was like: Japan bitch!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I wish I could come tonight.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (all the way back) Me too.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: We could get dinner next week?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Ahhh! Why now! No, I want to but Patch’s grandfather is real sick and we're all going to Chicago for these special treatments. Their whole family goes. Being sick when you're rich is totally awesome. They replace all his cells or something. That can’t be right, but that’s what it is in my mind.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Where are you so I can picture it?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m in Patch’s study. 98 We CUT TO Sophie sitting in a leather chair at a desk.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’ve never seen it. My picture’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: We'll be coming back to New York a lot, we'll just be based in Tokyo.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You’11l learn Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: We can video chat. 21st century, what up.  Revision (05/14/2012) 75.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: My computer doesn’t have that.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: New places are good for you, I think.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (observing the chain restaurant around her) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You should travel, Fran.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I am. (lies for some reason) I’m going to. (nearly crying, genuine) I'm happy for you, I just...no, you know what? I’m just happy for you.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: We're going to have a blog.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Together?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, BARF. We'll upload pictures and stories and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Homeless and vacation have some similarities.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry I missed your Christmas show...I guess I was mad.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: -- it’s okay. I didn’t...it wasn’t so good anyway.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: How’s all that going?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Um, pretty good. Great. I havea meeting on Monday with Colleen to talk about stuff.  Revision (05/14/2012) 76.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You'll finally be in the company? For real?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’1l probably be touring, though.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: That’s so great Fran.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (letting her assume) Yeah, it is.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Where are you living? I heard you're not with the boys anymore. Hey, you wanna live in our apartment while we’re in Japan?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: No. I. No. (pause, deciding) I’m going to have my own place real soon.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Maybe one day I’1l stay with you!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Maybe. Um, I should go. (beat) Thanks for calling, Sophie. I'm...I’m sorry too.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Apology accepted.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (bristling) Well, don’t be a dick about it!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I wasn't!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I mean this phone call is costing me a fortune!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (lying) . ; Just kidding. It isn’t. Hey, is Abby in Paris now, do you know?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You sound really good Frances.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I am. I am really good. Thanks for calling. I’m going to say something but I’m going to hang up right after because I don’t want you to feel obligated to say something back. I love you Sophie bye. She hangs up hastily.
99 Frances looks at the times for whatever lame American mov are playing. EXT. She EXT. She INT. Her INT.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: When did X-Men start?

dialogues.speaker: PARIS STREET
dialogues.text: walks more. Looks at her phone. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS APARTMENT
dialogues.text: puts her key in the lock...

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT. EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: phone alarm goes off. Frances startles.

dialogues.speaker: AIRPLANE. NEXT DAY
dialogues.text: Frances reads a fashion magazine.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAB FROM JFK. LATE DAY
dialogues.text: Frances sits in the back. suddenly lights up with a message. She looks exhausted. She listens. 100 101 102 103 104 Her phone  105 106 78. ABBY’S MESSAGE Frances, honey, we just got your messages, I don't know why they didn't come through before. We're here! We'd love to see you. This is total kismet: You remember Gerard, Nicholas's brother? The one who looks like Jean Pierre Leaud? Well, he's divorced now and staying with us. I think you'd really like him. Come to dinner tonight, he'll be there, as well as a philosopher and painter couple who are really great... Oh, what great timing. Frances hangs up her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances sits in a waiting area. She’s dressed in dance clothes. Colleen pokes her head out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Hey, you, come on in! INT. COLLEEN’S OFFICE 106 Colleen moves behind her desk. Frances sits.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Rachel said you were in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I was.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: You’re back so soon.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Well, we had our meeting.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: We could have moved it. I almost cancelled it myself this morning-- I woke up with a tickle in my throat. Frances nods. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Do you want to take over Nancy’s position?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Nancy's pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, no. I don’t. Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: No, I’m asking you. I mean, I assumed you’re not keeping on with the company. Frances hesitates. It’s so hard to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: (sympathetic) I know it’s hard, but it’s probably best.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (not sure why she’s agreeing) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: You don’t want to be an apprentice for the rest of your life.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: You know, you should think about putting your own stuff together.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Like how?

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Like your own work.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Eh, I don’t know, I kind of stopped doing it after college. And that was basically, like, cheerleaders doing my choreography.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: I always liked the stuff you did, even for the kids. 79.  80.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Listen, you should think about taking Nancy’s position. It’s not a lot of money, but it’s enough to keep you going...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Why would I do that?

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Just a good day job while you figure out if you want to choreograph or what.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You're saying it like it’s easy.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: No, it’s not easy. But if you worked here you could use the studio space -

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: - I'll get something else. (lying) . I’m really close to getting something.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: A job?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah. Dancing. I’m still going to be a dancer, just not here.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Oh. Good for you. That’s great.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN
dialogues.text: Well, good luck Frances.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah. Good luck to you, too.  107 Revision (05/14/2012) 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances hikes. Alone. Breathing and walking. Lots of tree She gets to the top of something. Gets out her phone. Cal

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Hi Mom.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Hi Mom.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: PAUL PICK UP THE OTHER PHONE. How is it up there?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Good, good. I’m dancing - kind of - .-+-and I’m living in a dorm I never got to live in before, which is fun. All the RA’s live in dorms.

dialogues.speaker: NOT THE ONE IN THE LIVING ROOM THE
dialogues.text: BATTERY IS DEAD. Is it strange to be back?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: No - it’s kind of nice. It’s so empty in the summer. It’s weird - it’s like I went back to college but everyone was a dancer and not a semiotics major.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: That must be fun for you, though.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: --and now I’m one of the adults...I keep thinking I’m going to run into Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (getting on the phone) Hi honey!

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Sophie e-mailed me a picture of her and Patch in the largest dog park in the world - I think I'd really like that about Japan.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I got a picture of them at a porn mall.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Do you have enough money?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean, I’m still in debt from Paris. That was just stupid.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: I’m sorry we can’t help out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You help out so much. I’11 be okay. They pay me extra to work the events.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: You aren’t a good waitress.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It’s not waitressing, it’s, like, pouring. For donors.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Are you choreographing?

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Paul, we went over this!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: At least you can’t spend money in nature.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Where are you right now?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances is in a T-Shirt that says “ASK ME!” Another girl on the same T-Shirt.  83.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: We don’t have to, like, guide them, personally, do we?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I think we just have to make sure that they don’t fuck or die.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Ah. Good. Because I’m having a Walden’s Pond moment.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You have a pond?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You know I found something out about Walden’s Pond - it was five minutes from his mom’s house. He would go over there and get supplies.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: So where are you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (confused) Here?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: No, where do you go to college?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m not, I don’t go. I’m done with college. But I went here... (does a flourish) --when I was younger.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Weird! For some reason I thought you HAD to be in college to do this.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Nope...I just wanted to get out of the city and I know the director of the summer program, so she hooked it up...and it had room and board...and I’m working the events to make more money.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Wow, you’re super responsible.  109

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: No. I’m not. (pause) It wasn’t that long ago that I went here. I’m only twenty-seven. The girl doesn’t care. Two young-ish looking dancers looking confused and carrying lots of luggage.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Fuck. I don’t know any answers. Don’t ask me! INT. COLLEGE CAMPUS. DANCE STUDIO. AFTERNOON. Frances walks in to the back of a class. It’s mostly aged students. A Dance Teacher approaches Frances.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE TEACHER
dialogues.text: Are you with the program?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m assisting.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE TEACHER
dialogues.text: Oh great, you’re one of the teachers?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Um, no, not, I’m RAing and just - but I’m a dancer -

dialogues.speaker: DANCE TEACHER
dialogues.text: - Oh, I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DANCE TEACHER
dialogues.text: We can’t let Resident Assistants take class.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: But I’m not just an RA.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE TEACHER
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, I don’t make the rules.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m a dancer. And I went here. 84. walk up 109 college-  112 113 85.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE TEACHER
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, I have to start class...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances is watches the students taking the class that she not allowed to take. They’re really good. It’s simultaneously inspiring and depressing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances caters, serving tiny food on big plates; pours wi into empty glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances is back in to get more food. A chef looks at her suggestively:

dialogues.speaker: CHEF
dialogues.text: You're a really good waitress.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m not a waitress. I just pour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances drinks with the catering people. It’s a college b They are all wearing white shirts and black pants. They a all younger than her.

dialogues.speaker: MALE CATERER
dialogues.text: Okay, I have one: Who do you have to apologize to? Everyone thinks.

dialogues.speaker: MALE CATERER
dialogues.text: I'll go: Everyone I've talked shit about over the past year. People laugh.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I owe a bed and breakfast money...

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CATERER
dialogues.text: No, that’s not the same.  86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances walks into a dark dorm building. Stumbles towards room. A very annoyed looking girl is waiting for her ther

dialogues.speaker: ANNOYED GIRL
dialogues.text: (loud whisper) You were supposed to be on duty ten minutes ago!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (normal voice) Sorry, I was -

dialogues.speaker: SHHHHHHHH
dialogues.text: Frances tiptoes around the other girl and into her room. 115 INT. DORM. FRANCES’ ROOM. NIGHT. 115 Frances flops down on her single bed. The room is totally undecorated, a college dorm room in the summer. The weird blonde wooden furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances’ wakes up in the dark. She gets out of bed and wa down the hallway. Goes to the bathroom. On the walk back her room, she sees a Younger Girl crying.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Frances hesitates. Then decides the girl needs someone:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (sitting down next to her) I’m just going to sit here, okay?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER GIRL
dialogues.text: You don’t have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m just going to, though. Frances sits and the Younger Girl cries.  Revision (05/14/2012) 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances stands at one of three computers, the other two a taken. She checks her e-mail and looks at the joint Japan blog that Sophie and Patch have. A student looks on:

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Are you going to study abroad there?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh I’m not a student. There’s no more abroad.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: I’m half Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: My best friend kind of lives there now. She drifts off. The student looks slightly annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: (re: computer) Are you done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances smokes a cigarette. A campus security guard comes of the woods.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: You can’t smoke here!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (dropping her cigarette) Oh sorry --

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: -- No, don’t put it out! God damn it! They scuffle for the butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The co-ordinater of the catering company is giving assignments. He’s standing with Frances and pointing to t back of a woman’s head at the party.  120 Revision (05/14/2012) 88.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Famous how?

dialogues.speaker: CATERING BOSS
dialogues.text: She’s a senator or a congresswoman or something. She’s important.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I should read the news more.

dialogues.speaker: CATERING BOSS
dialogues.text: Your job tonight is to follow her. Just make sure she’s taken care of. She just gave the school a TON of money. You don’t leave until she leaves - got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances, in her catering uniform, stands behind the Congresswoman during the reception after the auction. Frances gets the Congresswoman different drinks and foods always with her. The Congresswoman flirts with a Young Ma Frances tries to not pay attention.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSWOMAN
dialogues.text: (sexily) Well when I went here it was all girls. To meet a boy you had to take the “Fuck Truck” to Hoboken.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (interrupting) You went here? Excuse me. You went to here?

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSWOMAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh my god, that makes so much sense! I knew you looked familiar. You were on the freakin’ brochures! I’m Frances, I went here.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSWOMAN
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Frances.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You too! Sorry, sorry. I’m not really supposed to talk to you...I’m pouring.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSWOMAN
dialogues.text: Ah, yes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (confidentially) You're very inspiring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances stands behind the Congresswoman and the Very Youn Man. Holds a wine bottle. Frances hears a girl crying and a man saying:

dialogues.speaker: MAN VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t cry, baby, don’t cry, baby.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don’t care!

dialogues.speaker: MAN VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I care.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You bought the CHEAPEST auction thing. THE CHEAPEST.

dialogues.speaker: MAN VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I didn’t even go here! Frances drifts in the direction of the fight. She turns a corner: It’s Sophie who’s crying. Patch consoling her. Frances ca believe it. Stares. Then retreats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances is trying to avoid being seen by Sophie and Patch Sophie walks straight up to the Congresswoman. Frances hi behind her:

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (drunkenly) You gave a GREAT speech, but I seriously can’t believe you’re an independent, because that’s bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Sorry. Sophie, let’s go.  90.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I went here. I thought you were great. I made him give money.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSWOMAN
dialogues.text: Well, good. Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: We live in Japan. So it’s like crazy we're here.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSWOMAN
dialogues.text: That’s wonderful that you came all the way back for the auction.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I WISH. No, we're in New York for a funeral. His grandpa. I wanted to come here. He drove. But it was MY idea.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSWOMAN
dialogues.text: Oh...I’m sorry for your loss.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It’s okay. His grandpa had a second family in Germany.

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: (stern) Sophie, let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (to the Congresswoman) I loved meeting you. A real honor. (indicating Patch) This douche is my affianced.

dialogues.speaker: CONGRESSWOMAN
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: We're engaged.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (from across the room)

dialogues.speaker: YOU'RE ENGAGED
dialogues.text: All eyes go to Frances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie and Frances talk. Frances keeps pouring wine for t Congresswoman. Sophie is messy drunk.  gl.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It’s not engaged engaged.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Right. What?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: We're back for going to a funeral. I would have called - but you’re touring with the company.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (lying) Yeah, I was, but you know, I needed a break and I thought it would be so funny to come back to the college for the summer.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It is funny! In a great way.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yeah. And just making extra money with this kind of gig.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. The Congresswoman continues to flirt with the Young Man.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (a little too loudly) What a slut.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Do you need some food?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (grabs a mini quiche) I‘1l just eat this.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I really didn’t expect to see you.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Ditto.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It’s almost hard to be happy about it because I didn’t have any time to anticipate it.  124 125 Revision (05/14/2012) 92.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (like in a bar trying to pick up a girl) Let’s get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I can’t. I have to shadow this woman -- she’s my...ward. The Congresswoman is full on making out with the Young Ma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Congresswoman gets into her car with the Young Man. Frances waits for the car door to close. She breaths a si of relief. Sophie and Patch are fighting as they get into their car.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m not going back to New York. I don’t want to go to the funeral tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: You have to go.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m hanging out with Frances. We’re going to the mall. Frances climbs into the back seat. INT. PATCH’S CAR. NIGHT. 125 Frances sits in the backseat. Patch drives and Sophie is the front seat. Sophie is still wasted:

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m bringing Frances to the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (to Sophie) I don’t want to go to the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You didn’t even know your grandpa. You didn’t hang out.

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: It’s a funeral. It doesn’t matter.  Revision (05/14/2012) 93.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: If you’re so broken up about it why did we go to the auction tonight?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I DON’T EVEN WANT YOU HERE!

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: You were wasted, I wasn’t going to let you drive.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (turning around) Frances, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: (to Frances) You don’t need to answer.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: How sad were you really when your Grandpa died?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Pretty sad. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (pause) Well, I wasn’t. (to Patch) And I don’t see why you should be.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, this is me, right up here. My dorm. Patch pulls up, Frances gets out. Patch and Sophie are st fighting.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (taking in her environment ) “Chuggins.” We never lived in this dorm.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I know. It’s like the life I never had! Anyway. Congratulations? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: On the engagement? (pause) And sorry for your loss.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (to Patch) You are so fucking selfish.

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Frances.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Don’t talk to her, don’t look at her. She’s my friend. She doesn’t even like you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I like you...

dialogues.speaker: PATCH
dialogues.text: (to Frances) I like you too, Frances. Patch pulls away. Frances’ face “what the fuck just happened?”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances is asleep. She is woken up by an insistent knocki at her door. It’s Sophie. She’s crying.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, come in.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Can I stay?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Of course. Come. Stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie is sitting on the bed, alone. There is a tapping o the door. She opens it. Frances is carrying two cups of tea.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It’s made in the microwave, but it’s good.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Thank you...I hope it’s okay I borrowed lounge wear.  128 95.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: No, of course. Sophie takes her tea and they both sit cross-legged on th bed.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (takes a sip of the tea, looks green) I think...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, shit, here - Frances puts a trashcan in front of her, Sophie throws up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lay side by side in a single bed. The bedside light on.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I was so drunk I threw up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I live in a dorm with a single bed. Sophie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Here, lay on the outside.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Okay. They switch places.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Put one foot on the floor. It helps you if you have the spins.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I used to throw up all the time when I was pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You were pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: In Japan. For a few weeks. Then I miscarried which was cool.  Revision (05/14/2012) 96.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I mean, that sounds crass - miscarriage is not cool.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Would you have had it?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Are you going to marry Patch?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I can’t believe that pregnant is no longer crazy.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to stay in Tokyo. I hate it there.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. And then when I got pregnant I was just like “get me the fuck out.”

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: But your blog looks so happy.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I don’t think my mom would read it if it were about depression.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: My mom would. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I was telling the truth. I like Patch. I don’t hate him.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I know.  Revision (05/14/2012) 97.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about...It’s just if something funny happens on the way to the deli, you’1ll only tell one person and that will be Patch. And I’1l never hear about it.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (sort of taking it in, sort of not, after a beat) Fuck I’m tired. Frances turns off the light.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: It’s bedtime for all good children.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I want to leave Patch and leave Tokyo and come back to New York.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You should!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m going to.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I could...I don’t know. I could help you. I was going to say “you could live with me,” but I don’t have a home. Ha.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I am going to do it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Fuck yeah, girl.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I miss my job. And I miss old skyscrapers.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Maybe we’1ll both move back to New York at the same time. We'll be like women who re-discover themselves after a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: That’s what my mom did.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I think it will be great.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: We should get apartments close to each other - in Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s what we’ll do. (pause) I've always felt so competitive with you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (surprised) Really? I don’t think I realized we were competitive. They are quiet for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Fran?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Can you...I know it’s not my bed, but...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Can you take off your socks?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, sure.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It’s just - socks in bed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Right. Gross. Frances takes off her socks and lies down again. Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I love you Frances. Goodnight.  129 130 99.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I love you Sophie. Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie is moving around the room quietly. Frances is stil sleeping. After she finishes getting dressed, she writes a note. CLOSE on the note as Sophie leaves. Frances wakes up a second later. She looks around confuse Sees the note. Reads it.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I was so drunk last night, but thank you for being nice to me which I know you were even though I don’t remember it. All I know is you don’t have a trash can this morning so it must have been bad! Ha ha. I love you. I’ve got to get back to this funeral in New York. Call me when you're awake! My phone works in the states and there aren’t any charges or anything. xoxo Sophie Without putting on shoes or a robe, Frances runs 130 downstairs and out to the parking lot in bare feet just t see Patch’s car turning out of the lot and onto the main road. Frances runs after the car onto the road.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: (calling) Sophie! Sophie! But Sophie doesn’t see or hear her. She’s gone. Frances l down at her bare feet and looks back up to the road. BLACK.  Revision (05/14/2012) 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances walking with her backpack and bomber jacket early the morning. She’s carrying a coffee mug, like she made i home. Or at least thought ahead enough to bring it with h and get it filled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gets out of the subway by City Hall. Walks through a hall of dancers we’ve seen her in before - maybe she’s dancing But nope. She’s -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances busily working at a development office. With Coll - she took the job she had rejected before. Making phone calls, doing things on spreadsheets, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances choreographs something in the park during lunch. She's enjoying herself. Dances. Takes a bite of a sandwich that she produced from paper bag. She’s brought a bagged lunch. A female co-work

dialogues.speaker: CO-WORKER
dialogues.text: We’re back in five, Frances. *

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Thanks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances is finishing up the day. People are leaving. She looks at the clock. Makes a phone call:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yes, hi, this is Frances...yes, “Frances for tonight”...ha thanks!...I just wanted to double check that we’re still on for me bringing my guys in a little * early...okay! Great! See you in thirty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An older woman lets Frances into the space.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER WOMAN
dialogues.text: I think the other two groups will be here by six forty five.  136 137 138 101.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: We'll be done by then, thanks! Frances puts her stuff down and physically explores the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of young dancers come in, all female, around twenty them. They all hug Frances, warm up, and run through a co of sequences. Frances checks the lights and sound boards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One company finishes up. Come out and bow. Lights go down Frances is up in the sound/light booth. Trades places wit the person who was there before her. She breathes hard, in and out, and turns the lights on an the sound up. Frances continues to run boards while her dancers perform There is a small audience. Frances is beaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are milling around, talking with their families an friends. It’s kind of a reception. It’s one of those thin where there was hardly anyone there who doesn’t know some who was performing. Colleen is there, Rachel is there, Frances’ ex-boyfriend, is there, Lev and a different hot girl. Benji approaches Frances.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Hey, that was great.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Aw, thanks Ben. I like a lot of ladies dancing.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Yeah, at times it reminded me of...Antonioni’s Zabriskie Point... (beat) Undateable.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: No, I meant me that time.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, Zabriskie Point.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: But also true. Meaning I’m not dating anyone. Undateable. Same difference.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: BENJI
dialogues.text: Are you really, still, are you - undateable?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: You mean am I, oh, yes. Yes I am. Very undateable. Benji and Frances have a half-moment. Frances greets more people, takes pictures, laughs. Colle is there, congratulates her. This is the high point of Frances’ twenty-seven years. Then, across the room, Frances sees Sophie. At first Soph doesn’t see her. Patch enters frame and puts his arm arou her. She holds up her hand to someone. She has a ring.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You guys got married! Frances looks away, surveys the crowd of people who came see her show. She smiles. She looks back. Sophie is watching her. They catch each other’s eye and kind of smile. It’s the moment that Frances has always wanted. They are sharing a life-long inside joke.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who are you making eyes at?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: That’s Sophie. She’s my best friend. They keep looking at each other, kind of laughing, kind o emotional. No one breaks.  139 140 141 103. CLOSE on Sophie looking at Frances. CLOSE on Frances looking on Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Frances’ hand writing something. It’s her name. Frances cuts out the name from the sheet of paper. She’s sitting at the kitchen table of a small just-moved-into pretty empty apartment. She walks out and trots down a flight of stairs to a bank of mailboxes. She finds 2B and opens it. CLOSE on Frances sliding the piece of paper into the mail slot. It doesn’t quite fit. She has to fold it to get it into the space. Once it is in, it just reads:

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES HA
dialogues.text: We hold on the title. Roll CREDITS over the image.
